description.narrative:
Mopti is located between the Northern and Southern parts of Mali. Through this proximity, many young people displaced from the North have found refuge in Mopti. The school authorities have had to manage the incoming flow of students. This displacement exacerbatesthe vulnerability of young people in general and girls in particular, in the context of crisis and war. This population displacement also increases young people#s needs for information on reproductive health. Moreover, the city of Konna, which has been the showplace of fighting between the Malian army and the jihadist groups, is situated near Mopti. Today Konna is in a situation of insecurityand vulnerability. The young people and particularly the students have increased needs for information on SRH. With the support of Oxfam Novib in 2013, One World UK partnered with Delta Survie to build the foundations of a project for the promotion and education of sexual and reproductive health. Delta Survie specializes in the field of education and works in Mopti with young people and adolescents on sexual and reproductive health. The introduction of sexual and reproductive health education using the eLearning platform will provide young people and adolescents with accurate and appropriate information, whether they are local or have been displaced. GOALS AND OBJECTIVES This extension of activities to Mopti will fit into the existing programme. It will contribute to the followinggoals and objectives of the « My Rights, My Voice » programme: Reinforce the capacities of young Malians to assert their rights and to protect them Effectively realize the right to quality education amongst children and young people, particularly of young girls.
Some expected results # Phase II will be launched in 10 new schools in Mopti, and Sévaré Konna # Nearly 50 teachers and 100 peer educators will be trained in Info ADO Nearly 3,000 courses will be taught by trained teachers 6000 students will have used the elearning platform in 9 months through the courses and activities of peer educators

participating-org.narrative:
OneWorld UK is one of the 13 centres of the OneWorld network, a worldwide participatory media network. Our centre’s specialty is innovating e-media tools and platforms to support our community of civil society organisations and global citizens. Members of our team created, for example: The world’ first global civil society portal on sustainable development and human rights in 1994-5 (www.oneworld.net) The world’s first search engine for civil society The world’s first platform for citizens’ video clips in 2001 We mix and match new media in all kinds of imaginative new ways so that people all over the world are able to speak up in order to improve their lives. Our valuable experiences of innovative ICT programmes have been gained from working with a wide range of local partner organisations in different countries and for different themes.
Since 2007, OneWorld UK has been implementing a project which uses ICT to address sensitive issues of sexuality and gender among young people in Nigeria, Senegal (2010) and more recently in 2011, in Morocco. This project, called Learning about Living, initially designed to use mobile phones and computers in schools, has continued to add on other forms of new media as well as traditional media like radio which is very popular in Africa, to engage young people in the different countries.
One World UK harnesses the power of the multimedia to help give a voice to the people ignored by the mainstream media and to mobilise people around the world. It brings people together from all over the world, to share ideas, speak out and make a difference, for which One World provides the platforms, tools and content. The One World network is a fast growing global community of people and civil society groups acting up for global justice. Its internet portal is an award-winning and trusted source of information and gateway to two million pages of text, images and audio and visual materials, produced by 1,600 partners, 1,000 broadcasters and 6,000 video-makers. It is delivered intwelve languages through eleven regional websites maintained by One World centres around the world. The One World International Foundation (OWIF) is the network's governing body and guardian of its vision, and isdedicated to working with others to makeits vision reality. OWIF was set up in December 1999 and registered as a UK charity in January 2003. In the past five years One World has gained valuable experience in innovative ICT programprograms, working with a wide range of local partner organisations. The first initiative was its Open Knowledge Network, a project of the G8 Digital Opportunity TaskForce that One World had set up. It is now running in ten countries and offers systems that give access at the village level, for people to create and share knowledge in their own language on issues that improve their opportunities in life.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
